subject: Psychology
title: Heroism and Moral Courage
description: A fast breakdown of Heroism and Moral Courage for builders.

hook.text: Oscar Schindler was a flawed, profit-seeking man. Yet he risked everything to save over a thousand lives.

buildup.text: Zimbardo shifted from studying evil to studying heroism. He asked: what makes ordinary people do extraordinary good?

discovery.text: Heroes aren't born. They respond to a situation with action while others freeze. The choice is made in seconds.

twist.text: Heroism training works. Teaching people to notice injustice and act despite risk increases heroic behavior.

climax.text: The same situational power that creates villains can create heroes â€” if people are prepared to act.

punchline.text: A hero is an ordinary person in an extraordinary moment of choice.

quiz.question: What did Zimbardo's research on heroism find?
options: Heroism can be trained and encouraged through preparation
Heroes are born with special personality traits
No one can be trained to act heroically
